By GEORGE L. RADCLIFFE, 0. B '97 Ph D.
Chairman of General Committee.

Alumni of the Johns Hopkins
University from all parts of the
United States, from Canada and
from "over the seas" will meet at
Homewood on June 19. They will
there have the opportunity and
privilege of meeting many of their
former classmates and associates
home from the war, and especially
in joining in memorial exercises

made the supreme sacrifice.

PROF. SMITH'S VACANCY FILLED
His Duties to be Assumed by Dr. Wilfred P. Mustard and Dr. Tenney
Frank.

Arrangements have just been
completed for filling the vacancy
in the Latin Department caused
by the lamented death of Prof.
Kirby Flower Smith.
Dr. Wilfred P. Mustard, who
has had charge of the post-graduate work of the Latin Seminary
ever since Dr. Smith's death, was
transferred some months ago from
the list of "collegiate" professors
to the "University" group. Dr.
Tenney Frank, of Bryn Mawr College, has recently been appointed
an additional professor of Latin,
and both he and Dr. Mustard will
take part in both graduate and
undergraduate work. A detailed
statement of the courses to be
offered next year will be published
at an early date.
Dr. Frank is an A. B. of the
University of Kansas, 1898, and a
Ph. D. of the University of Chicago, 1903. From 1901 to 1904 he
served on the classical staff of the
University of Chicago, and since
1904 he has been associate, associate professor and professor of
Latin at Bryn Mawr College. His
publicatigns show a wide range
of interests, with a special leaning
toward the political and economic
history of Rome. His most impor-

tant book is "A Study of Roman
Imperialism" (New York, 1914).

joining with former undergraduates to de her honor.

the alumni, but for the present
student body. The whole hearted
enthusiasm and participation of
all undergraduates must necessarily add to the slIcePSS of the reunion.

GLEE CLUB AT ROCKVILLE
1 HONOR SYSTEM EFFECTIVE
By Professor JOHN CALVIN FRENCH

[In this article, addressed to the
alumni, the chairman of the Committee
on Student Affairs praises the efficiency
of the Student Council in enforcing
it.—Es.]

A few years ago, in the special
number of THE NEWS-LETTER issued during a reunion of former
students, the alumni were informed that an honor system in
examinations had just been adopted at Johns Hopkins. Today the
editor asks me to tell briefly how
the system has worked. I am glad
to be able to say that in my judgment it has worked admirably and
has fulfilled the hopes of those
public-spirited students who took
the initiative in establishing it. It
is not, of course, one hundred per
cent. elicient. Not every student
has the ... strength of character
which the honor system presupposes, and it is possible that the
honor pledge is sometimes misused. But I am'convinced that
such cases are extremely rare; far
more rare than the evasions of
supervision that take place in colleges where the instructor polices
the examination room. Moreover,
the honor system produces a spirit
of mutual confidence between faculty and students and a sense of
responsibility in the leaders of
student opinion which are worth
a great deal. The Student Councils of the past few years have
had some difficult tasks. It has
been necessary for them to bring
offenders to trial, to sift evidence,
and to reach a verdict which involved the dismissal of the culprit
from college. I have been present
at. some of these trials, and have
been much impressed by the dignity and seriousness of the proceedings and by the justice of the
decisions. I can recall no recommendation made by such a student
court to the Dean that was not at
once given his official sanction. It
is a part of the Hopkins system
that the actions of the Student
Council in such matters are not
made public. They are, however,
reported to a committee of the
faculty, which co-operates closely with the Council. It is fair to
say that since the adoption of the
not a great
system a number
number, happily—of students have
been tried by their fellows, and
that some, having been proved
guilty, have been advised by the
Council to leave Homewood at
once. A student who did not wish
to accept this verdict was entitled
to a trial by the Dean and the
Committee on Student Affairs;
but no defendant has ever challenged the student sentence. I do
not wish to imply that the system is largely a matter of compulsion. For the most part, it enforces itself. I do, however, wish
to assure alumni that student selfgovernment at Hopkins is a reality and that when occasion arises
it governs.

PLEA TO A. B. S.
By HUGH JUDGE JEWETT, A. B. '92.
Chairman of "A. B." Committee.
Undoubtedly the greatest asset
of a public institution is the goodwill of the community it serves.
No record of efficiency, no proof
of merit, can assure its future unless the people are inclined to favor it.
Especially is this true of educational institutions, and particularly of those which depend chiefly
upon private benefactions.
Their most evident source of
support lies in their own alumni,
and ample testimony proves that
where the greatest enthusiasm and
attachment exists the most material support is afforded.
Accordingly, we are confronted
by a simple problem, namely: If
our college experiences have not
yet created in our hearts such emotions as inspire the alumni of
other colleges, how are we to
arouse in ourselves those dormant
instincts of devotion and sacrifice
by which we can aid our Alma
Mater to reap the full fruits of
her splendid motto?
The answer is as simple as the
problem: Let us first admit our
lebt. Let us next resolve as honest
men to make what material acknowledgement we may. And last,
let us once for all declare that we
shall lose no opportunity to place
ourselves on record as committed
to this policy.
In the future, therefore, let us
show that by deed's, not words, we
speak; and as a first step in proving that our allegiance is henceforth to be a real and vital force,
let us here and now unanimously
vote to attend the coming reunion,
where, by an exhibition of enthusiastic and energetic co-operation
the world may remain convinced
that the Johns Hopkins University lives pre-eminent, as heretofore.

A most interesting talk on
trade unions was delivered by Mr.
Ferguson, president of the American Federation of Labor, on Friday evening, May 23, before the
Social Science Club. The speaker
briefly •traced the history of trade
unions from their origin up to
their present status. Exclusive of
the old Roman working men
unions and the English guilds of
several centuries back, Mr. Ferguson stated that the beginning
of a real trade union came with
the organization of the Knights of
Labor. From this latter body the
present American Federation of
Labor has grown.
The American Federation of Labor has at present about three and
one-half million members in the
United States, including skilled
and unskilled workihgtnen. The
speaker also remarked, in reference to the radicalism of trade
unions, that all great movements
in the past have been radical ones,
and that all great men have been
more or less radical in their convictions, and surely trade unions
would not deny such a compliment.
Trade unions are a living protest against the present social conditions that destroy the life of the
toiler of America, and, therefore,
they are rendering an inestimable
service to humanity. Trade unions are working for education of
the workers, better wages, shorter
hours,and naturally they hope that
better living conditions will follow
in the wake of these. The only
way that trade unions can adequately handle unskilled labor in
the future is to prohibit all future
immigration of those not fit to
take care of themselves.
The motto of all labor is: "United we stand; divided we fall."

Arrangements have just been

in the Latin Department caused
by the lamented death of Prof.

to the "University" group. Dr.
Tenney Frank, of Bryn Mawr College, has recently been appointed
an additional professor of Latin,
and both he and Dr. Mustard will
take part in both graduate and
undergraduate work. A detailed
statement of the courses to be
offered next year will be published
at an early date.

University of Kansas, 1898, and a
Ph. D. of the University of Chicago, 1903. From 1901 to 1904 he
served on the classical staff of the
University of Chicago, and since
1904 he has been associate, associate professor and professor of
Latin at Bryn Mawr College. His
publicatigns show a wide range
of interests, with a special leaning
toward the political and economic
history of Rome. His most impor-

tant book is "A Study of Roman
Imperialism" (New York, 1914).

1 HONOR SYSTEM EFFECTIVE
By Professor JOHN CALVIN FRENCH

[In this article, addressed to the
alumni, the chairman of the Committee
on Student Affairs praises the efficiency
of the Student Council in enforcing
it.—Es.]

A few years ago, in the special
number of THE NEWS-LETTER issued during a reunion of former
students, the alumni were informed that an honor system in
examinations had just been adopted at Johns Hopkins. Today the
editor asks me to tell briefly how
the system has worked. I am glad
to be able to say that in my judgment it has worked admirably and
has fulfilled the hopes of those
public-spirited students who took
the initiative in establishing it. It
is not, of course, one hundred per
cent. elicient. Not every student
has the ... strength of character
which the honor system presupposes, and it is possible that the
honor pledge is sometimes misused. But I am'convinced that
such cases are extremely rare; far
more rare than the evasions of
supervision that take place in colleges where the instructor polices
the examination room. Moreover,
the honor system produces a spirit
of mutual confidence between faculty and students and a sense of
responsibility in the leaders of
student opinion which are worth
a great deal. The Student Councils of the past few years have
had some difficult tasks. It has
been necessary for them to bring
offenders to trial, to sift evidence,
and to reach a verdict which involved the dismissal of the culprit
from college. I have been present
at. some of these trials, and have
been much impressed by the dignity and seriousness of the proceedings and by the justice of the
decisions. I can recall no recommendation made by such a student
court to the Dean that was not at
once given his official sanction. It
is a part of the Hopkins system
that the actions of the Student
Council in such matters are not
made public. They are, however,
reported to a committee of the
faculty, which co-operates closely with the Council. It is fair to
say that since the adoption of the
not a great
system a number
number, happily—of students have
been tried by their fellows, and
that some, having been proved
guilty, have been advised by the
Council to leave Homewood at
once. A student who did not wish
to accept this verdict was entitled
to a trial by the Dean and the
Committee on Student Affairs;
but no defendant has ever challenged the student sentence. I do
not wish to imply that the system is largely a matter of compulsion. For the most part, it enforces itself. I do, however, wish
to assure alumni that student selfgovernment at Hopkins is a reality and that when occasion arises
it governs.

PLEA TO A. B. S.
By HUGH JUDGE JEWETT, A. B. '92.
Chairman of "A. B." Committee.
Undoubtedly the greatest asset
of a public institution is the goodwill of the community it serves.
No record of efficiency, no proof
of merit, can assure its future unless the people are inclined to favor it.
Especially is this true of educational institutions, and particularly of those which depend chiefly
upon private benefactions.
Their most evident source of
support lies in their own alumni,
and ample testimony proves that
where the greatest enthusiasm and
attachment exists the most material support is afforded.
Accordingly, we are confronted
by a simple problem, namely: If
our college experiences have not
yet created in our hearts such emotions as inspire the alumni of
other colleges, how are we to
arouse in ourselves those dormant
instincts of devotion and sacrifice
by which we can aid our Alma
Mater to reap the full fruits of
her splendid motto?
The answer is as simple as the
problem: Let us first admit our
lebt. Let us next resolve as honest
men to make what material acknowledgement we may. And last,
let us once for all declare that we
shall lose no opportunity to place
ourselves on record as committed
to this policy.
In the future, therefore, let us
show that by deed's, not words, we
speak; and as a first step in proving that our allegiance is henceforth to be a real and vital force,
let us here and now unanimously
vote to attend the coming reunion,
where, by an exhibition of enthusiastic and energetic co-operation
the world may remain convinced
that the Johns Hopkins University lives pre-eminent, as heretofore.

The first meet held under the
auspices of the Maryland Scholastic Athletic Association of the
Johns Hopkins University took
place at Homewood Field on Friday, May 30. The games were
more than a success. The track
was in first-class condition, giving
more than 350 athletes, representing 19 schools, an opportunity to
try out their ability. The showing
of the boys representing Tome,
Gilman, Poly, City and Central
High School of Washington was

Social Science Club has Mr. 'Ferguson
as its Speaker.

A most interesting talk on
trade unions was delivered by Mr.
Ferguson, president of the American Federation of Labor, on Friday evening, May 23, before the
Social Science Club. The speaker
briefly •traced the history of trade
unions from their origin up to
their present status. Exclusive of
the old Roman working men
unions and the English guilds of
several centuries back, Mr. Ferguson stated that the beginning
of a real trade union came with
the organization of the Knights of
Labor. From this latter body the
present American Federation of
Labor has grown.
The American Federation of Labor has at present about three and
one-half million members in the
United States, including skilled
and unskilled workihgtnen. The
speaker also remarked, in reference to the radicalism of trade
unions, that all great movements
in the past have been radical ones,
and that all great men have been
more or less radical in their convictions, and surely trade unions
would not deny such a compliment.
Trade unions are a living protest against the present social conditions that destroy the life of the
toiler of America, and, therefore,
they are rendering an inestimable
service to humanity. Trade unions are working for education of
the workers, better wages, shorter
hours,and naturally they hope that
better living conditions will follow
in the wake of these. The only
way that trade unions can adequately handle unskilled labor in
the future is to prohibit all future
immigration of those not fit to
take care of themselves.
The motto of all labor is: "United we stand; divided we fall."
